title: 112_hr4231
content: The Gas Rebate Act of 2012, also known as the "Gas Rebate Act," repeals the enhanced oil recovery credit for oil and gas companies. The Gas Rebate Act of 2012 repeals the enhanced oil recovery credit for oil and gas companies. Subpart D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for inflation in taxable years after 2009. The Gas Rebate Act of 2012 repeals the enhanced oil recovery credit for oil and gas companies and adjusts dollar amounts for inflation in taxable years after 2009 based on the GNP implicit price deflator. The Secretary must publish the inflation adjustment factor by April 1 each year. Section 196 of the Code is amended to renumber paragraphs. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. Basis reductions continue for credits before December 31, 2012. SEC. 102 repeals the credit for producing oil and gas from marginal wells, while SEC. 103 repeals the expensing of intangible drilling and development costs. These amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. SEC. 103 repeals the expensing of intangible drilling and development costs for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. SEC. 106 repeals percentage depletion for oil and gas wells for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 eliminates section 613A and makes conforming changes to section 45H. It defines a related person for tax purposes based on ownership interests. The text discusses the definition of a related person for tax purposes based on ownership interests, including significant ownership interest criteria for corporations, partnerships, and estates/trusts. SEC. 107 amends the tax code to disallow deduction for income from oil and gas activities. It includes changes to section 199(c)(4) and subsection (d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. SEC. 108 amends the tax code to allow for a 7-year amortization period for geological and geophysical expenditures, effective for expenses incurred after December 31, 2012. Each registered motor vehicle owner as of the enactment date is considered to have made a payment against the tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code for the taxable year, equal to the motor vehicle owner rebate amount. This rebate amount is calculated based on the number of vehicles registered by the person in the US, multiplied by the estimated revenue attributable to the Gas Rebate Act. The Gas Rebate Act of 2012 provides for a refund or credit for overpayments related to motor vehicles registered in the United States. The term "motor vehicle" is defined as a vehicle with at least 4 wheels primarily for use on public streets. No interest is allowed on overpayments. The Gas Rebate Act of 2012 allows refunds for overpayments on motor vehicles registered in the US with at least 4 wheels. Vehicles leased for 1 year or more are registered under the lessee's name. Government-owned vehicles are exempt. Coordination with state authorities is required. The Gas Rebate Act of 2012 allows refunds for overpayments on registered motor vehicles with at least 4 wheels in the US. The Secretary of the Treasury will work with State authorities to determine eligible vehicle owners and prevent errors in rebates.
